text:
Do you think simple human characters would be better or very similar to Mike, simple body shapes with a human like face? 
Is a reel showing human characters to the same quality as one with monster characters ranked higher when directly compared?
Iâ€™ll definitely aim to improve deformations, I struggled with the rig because of the skinny arms coming out of a bean like body.

To be honest Tom that's not my area so i  wouldn't want to sway you either way. But a human face (even a simple one) is a hard task to crack. Not saying it's not possible but you'd be taking on something tough. I guess it depends on where you want to end up.  If you want to be an animator you could animate anything: a sphere animated with great timing and personality will win fans way more than a half baked rig and animation will. Does that make sense? Recruiters and supervisors want to know you could slot into a team without too much todo. Showing you understand timing and intent is the key. So in some ways it doesn't matter what you animate.  Sure if you can animate and rig Gollum or Thanos then you will be fighting off the offers. But bear in mind these people see the best animators and riggers in the world day in day out. They aren't expecting the world from you as a new hire. Just potential and a willingness to get going.
Where do you interests lie? Facial anim? Body anim? Cartoony stuff or more realistic?
Lets narrow it down a bit
because focussing is the key. Do something really bloody well rather than lots of stuff in a half finished way
because that shows them you can start, iterate and finish something
show where you started, how you adjusted it (listened to mine and other's feedback) and then polished it to a final product

I have some animator / rigging friends at work that I can absolutely show stuff to. But I'd like you to think about how you might present it to them. Narrow down to just your best work and show them you mean business
